required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Adults In The Making Prevention Trial
clinical_study.official_title: Preventing Alcohol Use Among African American Youths

brief_summary.textblock: This study was a randomized prevention trial investigating the efficacy of the Adults in the Making (AIM) prevention program against a control condition. The primary outcome variable is alcohol use. The study sample were 367 African American seniors in high school and their primary caregivers. The AIM program is a 6 session (12 hour) family-centered intervention designed to deter alcohol use.

primary_outcome.time_frame: follow up at 27 months post baseline
primary_outcome.description: Past month frequency of alcohol use, item from Monitoring the Future Survey

primary_outcome.time_frame: follow up at 27 months post baseline
primary_outcome.description: Parent reported rule breaking and aggression sub-scales of the Child Behavior Checklist. The combined subscales yield a score ranging from 0-38 with higher scores indicating more conduct problems

secondary_outcome.time_frame: follow up at 27 months post baseline
secondary_outcome.description: parent reported depressed/anxious symptoms on a subscale of the Child Behavor Checklist that ranged from 0-24 with higher scores indicating more depressive or anxiety symptoms

secondary_outcome.time_frame: follow up at 6 months post baseline
secondary_outcome.description: parent reported scale assessed the extent to which the primary caregiver provided emotional support, was accessible to the youth, and discussed difficult issues with which the youth was dealing. The 15 item scale ranged from 15-60 with higher scores reflecting more protective caregiving.

arm_group.description: Families were assigned to receive a 6 session, 12 hour prevention program in their community.
Families were assigned to no intervention control.

intervention.description: The AIM prevention program, modeled after an existing family-based skills-training intervention in a group format for rural African American preadolescents, consists of six consecutive weekly group meetings held at community facilities, with separate parent and youth skill-building curricula and a family curriculum. Each of the six meetings includes separate, concurrent training sessions for parents and youth, followed by a joint parent-youth session during which the families practice the skills they learned in their separate sessions. Concurrent and family sessions each last 1 hour. Thus, both parents and youth receive 12 hours of prevention training.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Residence in county where sampling was targeted
- Youth self identified as African American or Black
Exclusion Criteria:
- Unable to complete survey measures or participate in intervention due to mental health concerns
